text:
Revelations about granting a Cypriot passport to a Malaysian wanted
03 Nov 2019, 18:43 by SigmaLive
Cypriot nationality has been acquired by internationally renowned broker Joe Low, who has been wanted for the past four years, according to a report by Politis newspaper.
In particular, the Malaysian authorities have withdrawn his passport, issued a arrest warrant, are wanted by Interpol, and have been sought by US, United Arab Emirates, Indonesia, Indonesia for assistance. India, Myanmar, China and Hong Kong.
Jho Taek Low is alleged to be involved in a multi-billion dollar theft scandal that broke out in 2015. According to a Bloomberg report, Lowe allegedly created a number of shell companies through which he channeled hundreds of millions, many of which ended up in his own accounts.
According to Citizen's report, as soon as the scandal broke out in 2015, involving even 30 executives of US investment firm Goldman Sacs, the Malaysian addressed the authorities of the Republic of Cyprus through the international company Henley & Partners specializing in real estate market. Following the procedures of the Cyprus Investment Plan, he received the Republic of Cyprus passport, the report reads.
According to international media, Lowe avoids arrest, moving to various cities in China, which so far have shown no willingness to extradite him despite the international warrant against him. The Malaysian authorities have always been reported by Bloomberg (How Malaysia's 1MDB Scandal Shook the Financial World: 23/10/2019) and has been identified and is expected to be issued by the authorities by the end of the year. Lowe himself, in an interview with a newspaper in Indonesia, claims that he did nothing illegal and that he was merely consulting the former Malaysian prime minister.
However, according to the same information, at first sight, Mr. Joe Low when he requested the Republic of Cyprus passport at the end of spring 2015 was not wanted. Nor were any warrants issued against him. It was certainly a major issue in all international media because it had become well known in the meantime.
Elsewhere the report states that Henley & Partners, which undertook to complete the naturalization of the 34-year-old businessman then turned to a well-known audit firm in Nicosia asking him to prepare the relevant applications and submit what was required by law for the naturalization of Loos by the Ministry of the Interior under Socrates Hassikou's ministry.
Citizen reports that Henley & Partners conducted an investigation into the Malaysian businessman. The research was undertaken by Thomson Reuters, which delivered it on June 2, 2015. Based on the Risk Table, which consisted of 14 chapters, Joe Low found a problem in 4 of the 14 chapters investigated. The investigation has shown a) that he has a problem as a politically exposed person b) that he is accused of money laundering c) that he is accused of fraud and violation of financial regulations and d) that there are a number of other risk factors ). All of this was recorded in a report that exceeded 100 pages. Risk-based, the Thomson Reuters report had four ratings, namely green, yellow, orange and red. All four categories that Mr. Lowe found troubled referred to orange and red.

AKEL requests explanations on the issue of a passport to a wanted businessman

Will this time the government respond?
Yet another success for the Anastasiadis - Alarm government in… promoting Cyprus internationally. They granted citizenship to perhaps the most sought-after businessman in the world, by the name of Joe Lowe, the Politis newspaper reports today.
We wonder what the government will do in this case:
· Will he put them in the newspaper with the news, as we have done with all the other cases of government scandal?
· Will she be silent again hoping that the "hide it" pass will catch her now?
· Will she take responsibility on others, as she is used to doing?
· Will it refute the well-known claim that Cyprus is targeted?
Whatever the government does, this news confirms the fact that the government, with its citizen concession industry, has exposed Cyprus internationally.
However, it is worth asking how this businessman's country has his passport withdrawn, Interpol looking for him and our government not getting the news that he is wanted. Is it possible that no one has contacted the authorities of the Republic of Cyprus in the international effort to locate the businessman?
Once again, the government is called upon to provide answers. Will he give them this time?
